figure_1.title: FIGURE 1.
figure_1.caption: PRISMA flowchart (scoping reviews [ScR]) applied to the current study.

figure_2.title: FIGURE 2.
figure_2.caption: Number of records by type of study over the years.

figure_3.title: FIGURE 3.
figure_3.caption: Number of community and clinical samples included in the review. Clinical insomnia sample (studies using insomnia groups exclusively or using insomnia groups compared with control groups); community sample (studies using community or general population samples); other clinical sample (studies using other clinical samples such as major depression or dementia); mixed clinical sample (studies using insomnia disorder and other clinical samples); and not applicable (records used in the current scoping review [ScR] but that they are not empirical studies).

figure_4.title: FIGURE 4.
figure_4.caption: Report of reliability indicators by study.

claims.sentence:
Search strategy
Figure 1 provides the flowchart of the present study.
Italy (n = 1; 2%) and Iran (n = 1; 2%) had lower levels of production among the countries with studies about sleep effort or GSES (Figure 2).
Moreover, the most common type of study in which the GSES was used was cross‐sectional (Figure 2).
The detailed list of sample types and sample sizes considering all records is displayed in Figure 3.

Clinical insomnia sample (studies using insomnia groups exclusively or using insomnia groups compared with control groups); community sample (studies using community or general population samples); other clinical sample (studies using other clinical samples such as major depression or dementia); mixed clinical sample (studies using insomnia disorder and other clinical samples); and not applicable (records used in the current scoping review [ScR] but that they are not empirical studies).Finally, it was notable that most of the publications did not report their own reliability indicators such as internal consistency, with the number of studies reporting an own internal consistency measure equal to those who showed reliability induction by omission (n = 16; Figure 4).

Figure 1 provides the flowchart of the present study.
Italy (n = 1; 2%) and Iran (n = 1; 2%) had lower levels of production among the countries with studies about sleep effort or GSES (Figure 2).
Moreover, the most common type of study in which the GSES was used was cross‐sectional (Figure 2).
The detailed list of sample types and sample sizes considering all records is displayed in Figure 3.

Clinical insomnia sample (studies using insomnia groups exclusively or using insomnia groups compared with control groups); community sample (studies using community or general population samples); other clinical sample (studies using other clinical samples such as major depression or dementia); mixed clinical sample (studies using insomnia disorder and other clinical samples); and not applicable (records used in the current scoping review [ScR] but that they are not empirical studies).Finally, it was notable that most of the publications did not report their own reliability indicators such as internal consistency, with the number of studies reporting an own internal consistency measure equal to those who showed reliability induction by omission (n = 16; Figure 4).
Italy (n = 1; 2%) and Iran (n = 1; 2%) had lower levels of production among the countries with studies about sleep effort or GSES (Figure 2).
Moreover, the most common type of study in which the GSES was used was cross‐sectional (Figure 2).
The detailed list of sample types and sample sizes considering all records is displayed in Figure 3.

Finally, it was notable that most of the publications did not report their own reliability indicators such as internal consistency, with the number of studies reporting an own internal consistency measure equal to those who showed reliability induction by omission (n = 16; Figure 4).
